Darling Father . After a fortnight without letters, this week brought 2
mails - July 19 + 27 with the deeply interesting accounts of the
Heart

of Yorkshire. I'm writing to Mother . My letters seem to behave in just
the same curious way. Well, we've had a terrific week, but
we've got our king crowned + Sir Percy + I agree that we are now
half seas over. The remaining half is the Congress + the
Organic
Law. Provided for a constitutional monarchy, a parliamentary government and a bicameral legislature.
By the way (secret) I told you the impossible problem
which
H M G His Majesty's Government
had presented to us at the last moment + the rejoinder of
Faisal + Sir Percy.
H. M. G. His Majesty's Government
climbed down at once, I may say
grovelled. It was all a mistake + far from their intention
to interfere + God bless us all. Thereat we went gaily forward.
On Monday night I dined en famille with Ja'far + Nuri + their
wives + Ja'far's young brother Tahsin , inspector of police at
Samarra , a very good + capable young man. It was a happy
evening. Ja'far + Nuri were brimming over with joy + I not less.
The enthronement took place at 6 a.m. on Tuesday, admirably
managed. A dais about 2
ft feet
6 high was set up in the middle
of the big Sarai courtyard; behind it are the quarters Faisal
is occupying, the big Government reception rooms; in front we
were seated in blocks, English, Arab officials, townsmen,
ministries, local deputations, to the number of 1500. We came
in by ticket through the Sarai gateway + after the function had
begun the Arab police let no one in, whereby a good many magnates
who strolled along late were, to their pained surprise, excluded.
It was all Arab organization + it was quite right. Just
before I left my house Haji Naji rolled up on his way to
the ceremony, so I put him into my motor + we drove down
together. Lady Cox , the Garbetts , Mr Slater + I + one or two
GHQ General Headquarters
men were in the front English now. Exactly at 6 we saw Faisal
in uniform, Sir Percy in white diplomatic uniform with all
his ribbons + stars, Sir Aylmer , Mr Cornwallis , + a following of
ADC aide-de-camp
s descend the
Sarai steps from Faisal's lodging + come pacing down the
long path of carpets, past the guard of honour (the Dorsets,
they looked magnificent) + so to the dais. With them was

Saiyid Mahmud , the eldest son of the Naqib + Saiyid Husain Afnan ,
secretary to the Council of Ministers . We all stood up while they came
in + sat when they had taken their place on the dais. Faisal
looked very dignified but much strung up - it was an agitating
moment. He looked along the front row + caught my eye + I gave
him a tiny salute. Then Saiyid Husain stood up + read Sir
Percy 's proclamation, in which he announced that Faisal had
been elected king by 96% of the people of Mesopotamia , long live
the King! with that we stood up + saluted him, the national flag was
broken on the flagstaff by his side + the band played God
Save the King - they have no national anthem yet. There
followed a salute of 21 guns, during which, Saiyid Mahmud,
very inappropriately, read a prayer of thanksgiving to God +
ended by doing homage to Faisal on behalf of the Council.
Major Ditchburn from the wild Nasiriyah country told me
that when the guns began, one of the hawk-like Sa'dun
chiefs who was sitting by him, said "Hadha al hachi! )
- that's the talk!" Well, I suppose it is the ultimate talk
everywhere. King Faisal I then addressed his people. We have
telegraphed the text of the speech home so you will have read
it. It hadn't the free élan of his impromptu speeches - it
was so important a pronouncement that he had written it
down + read it out, turning to Sir Percy when he came to
the part about Great Britain . It was however very fine + simple +
heartfelt. With that they walked away as they had come +
we remained seated for a bit till Sir Percy + the General
passed out in their cars whereat we all began to go away,
talking + exchanging greetings + compliments + congratulations.
It was an amazing thing to see all 'Iraq, from north to south,
gathered together. It is the first time it has happened, in
history. So I went back to the office, breakfasted with
the Coxes + received masses of people who came in for

2
a little excited gossip. One of them was 'Ali Sulaiman of
the Dulaim. "By God" he said " Sir Percy Cox looked like the moon
among them (the moon is masculine in Arabic) + his face
looked like the heavens." I heard from others that the great
excitement among
shaikhs Honorific title meaning 'Elder', used for leaders of tribes and royal family members.
from remote places who hadn't met Sir
Percy before, was to see him. It's a good thing that he is such a
figure when you do see him; with his gaunt height + eagle's
beak he was very striking.
High
He looks so benevolent
as well as so strong.
I had a dinner party of 8. Major Ditchburn + his
Mutasarrif Governor of an administrative district.
who is Ibrahim Beg Sa'dun - his position as governor is a
little difficult because he can't read or write; none of the Sa'dun
can; 'Abdullah Beg Sa'dun whom I described to you last week,
'Abdul Majid Shawi , Mustafa Chalabi Sabunji , one of the
magnates of Mosul - I wish I remembered who the two
other big wigs were but I've completely forgotten. The Sa'dun
were in Beduin clothes, the Chalabi in robes + a turban,
Abdul Majid in a European suit + a fez. It went very
well. Ahmad Pasha Sana' of Basrah , who doesn't dine,
you remember, had been to tea with me + we had had a
long talk over the Basrah situation during which he
explained that though Basrah wanted to be part of the
'Iraq , its desire was to preserve a closer link with us
than other parts of the 'Iraq seemed to wish for. I said
that was all right as long as they would form an
integral part of the 'Iraq + send members to the elective
assembly.
Next morning Sir Percy + his staff were the fist to
attend Faisal 's levy. It began at 7.30. Sir Percy went
in first, then Mr Garbett , then I. Faisal stood before his
throne, Sir Percy on his right, Mr Garbett on his left, + I,
after making my curtsey to Faisal, on Sir Percy's left, while

all the British staff of the office filed past, like a Court.
(I wore my
C B E Commander of the Order of the British Empire
star + my 3 war ribbons - for the first time at the coronation)
We 3 with Faisal + Mr Cornwallis then sat down
in a corner of the room + had coffee till the
C in C Commander in Chief
came in to say his party was ready. Then
we left. Late in the afternoon the Coxes gave a
tiny party in their garden - Faisal had said he would
like to come + thank Sir Percy . The
C in C Commander in Chief
+ his
staff were there, Mr Cornwallis,
Col.
Colonel
Joyce + we
of Sir Percy's staff, the Garbetts + I. It was
extremely pretty, on a grass lawn under the palm trees.
Faisal brought half a dozen of his staff + we
all sat + talked for an hour + eat ices. I then
had another dinner party of 8, 'Abdul Latif Pasha
Mandil + Haji Mahmud Na'mah of
Basrah
,
Capt
Captain
Cook , adviser to
Auqaf + 4 Mosulis, the Minister of Auqaf , the Mayor ,
the Naqib + the Qadhi . That was a very interesting
party. The Qadhi of Mosul is perhaps the most darling old
man in the whole of 'Iraq , white, in his white robe, looking
very wise + very gentle. The Minister of Auqaf is a sprightly
old boy, full of vivacity + good sense. The Naqib is a
man, a little over 30, green turbaned + dark. He is not
worth much, one way or the other but he is a direct descendant
of the Prophet - as indeed are the two others - + his
family whole hold the firman of Naqibship given other them
by Timur Leng . It is written in Jagatai Turkish which
they can't read - a document of respectable age. The
Mosul
saiyids Muslim honorary title
are a very important section of the town.
They are all descended from a common ancestor who
came to Mosul some 800 years ago. In the midst of this
company of divines 'Abdul Latif Mandil struck a
divergent note. He is a
Najdi Originating from the Najd region of Saudi Arabia.
, with the sharp fine

3
features of the Arab of inner Arabia- his father
settled in Basrah - + he is possibly the most forceful
personality in the country now that Talib has gone.
It is he who has started + organized the Basrah
petition asking to remain under us - + why? he's
a great merchant + he wants to fish in the quietest
waters he can find - quieter than those that flow
through Arab kingdoms. He gave pretty forceful expression
to his views at dinner. + Then we began to talk of Kirkuk
+ the Minister of Auqaf called God to witness that for his
part he would only be too thankful if Kirkuk separated
from 'Iraq , for their
waqf Endowment; philanthropic deed in perpetuity.
didn't pay its own way + they
did nothing but quarrel among themselves over it. Whereat
the company laughed. But the Qadhi looked up + spoke at
some length on the Kurdish question, very wisely.
I've remembered the other two guests at my first party:
The Mutasarrif of 'Amarah , Salih Basha'yan , as clever as a
bagful of monkeys he is, + I like him with his nephew 'Abdul
Qadir Basha'yan who gave that big tea-party to Ja'far in Cairo .
Sir Percy had been very unwell, but on the day of the Coronation
he began to recover + is now quite fit again. So I, who had
kept all people off him for a week, quickly arranged for
the deputations to pay their respects to him. We had two days
of it, Friday + Saturday morning. It would be difficult to tell
you how many people there were in the office at one + the same
time. It was immensely interesting seeing them - there were
people I had never seen before + a great great many
who had never seen Baghdad before. Basrah + 'Amarah
came on Friday, Hillah + Mosul on Saturday; they
were the big deputations. Of these Mosul was the most
wonderful. I divided it into 3 sections: first the Mosul town
magnates, my guests + their colleagues: next the Christian
archbishops + bishops - Mosul abounds in them - + the

Jewish Grand Rabbi. One of the Christians was little Mar
Shim'un , archbishop + ruler of the Nestorians. The post
goes in the family, from uncle to nephew, for they
are
celibate celebate
, + he was elected last year on the
death of his uncle. He is 10, poor little soul, + there
he is in full canonicals + a great gold cross + chain,
doomed to be an archbishop all his days. The third group
was more exciting than all the others: it was the
Kurdish chiefs of the frontier who have elected to come
into the 'Iraq state until they see whether an independent
Kurdistan develops which will be still better to their liking.
I knew only one of them before, Sa'id Beg the religious
head of the Devil Worshippers whom I had seen as a child
of 7 or 8 when I stayed with his father in 1909. We
fell on one another's neck; he remembered quite well coming
to sit in my tent, which he did all the time I was there.
Some of the others were tremendous people. Shaikh Nuri
of Briefka, white haired, white turbaned + robed, holds
the population of a large section of the frontier in his
hand for this world + the next, for he is a spiritual
as well as a mundane dictator. Qadir Agha of Shush
deals with no world but this, but he deals with it
pretty thoroughly - in Kurdish, he has no other tongue.
He is a huge man + gigantically fat. He wears
acres of baggy striped trousers gathered round his
pretence
waist with a string, the jauntiest of fancy waistcoats + the
largest of Kurdish Kolehs on his head with a whole
shawl wrapped round it. He's worth seeing - I may say
it's a privilege to see him.
After they had had their quarter of an hour with Sir
Percy , all in time came down to me. The Kurds came last

4
+ stayed longest. The Mayor of Zakho opened the talk. He said
they hadn't had opportunity to discuss with Sir Percy the
future of Kurdistan , what did I think about it? I said that
my opinion was that the districts they came from were
economically dependent on Mosul + always would be,
however many Kurdistans were created. They agreed but,
said Shaikh Nuri , they must have Kurdish officials. I
said I saw no difficulty there. And the children must be
taught in Kurdish in the schools. I pointed out that there would
be some difficulty about that as there wasn't a single school
book - nor any other - written in Kurdish. This gave
them pause + after consideration they said they thought the
teaching might as well be in Arabic, but what about local
administrative autonomy? I said 'Have you talked it
over with Saiyidna Faisal - our Lord Faisal?" "No" they
said. "Well, you had better go + do it at once" I
suggested. "Shall I make an appointment for you?" "Yes"
they said. So I telephoned to Rustam Haidar + made
an appointment for yesterday afternoon - I'm longing
to hear from Faisal what came of it. Fun, isn't it.
I had spent two hours with Faisal the day before.
He asked me to tea; I brought him photographs of our
picnics (one of which I send to you) + a map of Syria taken
from the Times showing the way the French have cut up Syria
into separate provinces. He loved the photographs + swore of
over the map. "By God, it's forbidden" he said + we proceeded
to talk shocking heresy about Syria. Soon after Ja'far , Nuri +
Rustam (he's a Syrian) dropped in. I told them that except
for Rustam I thought I knew Syria better than any of them +
loved it more - village by village, mountain by mountain,

river by river. And I thought believed there was only one hope for Syria ,
that we should sit quiet here, say no word, + do our
own job. When we had made Mesopotamia a model Arab
state, not an Arab of Syria + Palestine that wouldn't
want to be part of it, + before I died I looked to see Faisal
ruling from the Persian frontier to the Mediterranean. But if
we stirred here in the matter, lifted a finger or raised a
voice it would be ruin to Syria + 'Iraq alike. This was
partly because Manlud Pasha who is what Ja'far calls
"donkey first class" has been going about Mosul saying
that whatever Faisal orders he intends to reconquer
Syria. It was he who led the attack against us on the
Euphrates last year, disobeying Faisal's repeated commands.
It would be a little comic if after conquering Dair from
the north + driving out the British administration in 1920,
he took Dair from the south + drove out the French administration
in 1920 1921! but of course we shall not let him.
We then spent a happy hour discussing (a) our desert
frontier to south + west + (b) the national flying +
Faisal's personal flag. For the latter we arranged
provisionally this
Sketch showing a design for a flag.
i.e. the Hijaz flag
with a gold crown
on the red triangle. The red I must tell you is
the colour of his house so he bears his own name
on it. Father , do for Heaven's sake tell me
whether the Hijaz flag is heraldically right.
You might telegraph. It's a very good flag + we
could differentiate it for the Iraq by putting

5
a gold star on the black stripe or on the red triangle. The
Congress will settle it directly it meets - do let me
know in time. Also whether you have a better
suggestion for Faisal 's standard.
By the time we had finished it was after sunset. Faisal
jumped up, put on his cap + said "I must go + pray." -
off he went + I with Ja'far through the throne room meaning
to go away but Ja'far said "Khatun, do stay a minute"
+ took me out onto the balcony over the Tigris . What he wanted
to ask me about was the new Cabinet. It was amazing, the red light
over the river, the hot night + Ja'far's anxious talk.
Nothing else is being talked of, naturally. One of the local
papers has offered a prize to anyone who rightly estimates
the number of candidates for office. That very afternoon
Naji Suwaidi had been to me + said he didn't want the
Interior (which is the most important ministry) because
he would be besieged by people wanting jobs. I said I
had heard him mentioned for Justice + he replied that
he would take that. This was a valuable admission
for neither Sir Percy nor the Naqib , who has been asked to
be
P.M. Prime Minister
, would like Naji. They think he is able enough but
not stable enough for this very crucial time. I think myself
he would probably do all right + Faisal would specially
like him but knows that Sir Percy wouldn't feel happy
about it. He (Faisal) therefore, looking round for a loyal man, rather wildly
proposed Ja'far. Ja'far is loyal to the back bone but he
couldn't tackle the Interior + moreover he must not leave
Defence , in the middle of creating an Arab army. Ja'far
began by saying that. He then suggested Naji + I told him
what Naji had just told me - a very useful card. Ja'far
then mentioned Hamdi Pachahji , who wouldn't do at
all: he's an idle, conceited, clever creature. I think

I persuaded Ja'far on that head. "What about Nuri ?" he said. I
replied that I loved Nuri but he was too young + had
no administrative experience Ja'far looked more + more
fatly perplexed. Now I must tell you that the man Sir
Percy wants for this interim, during which we summon
+ guide the Congress while it makes the
Organic Law, Provided for a constitutional monarchy, a parliamentary government and a bicameral legislature.
is Ahmad Pasha Sana' . Ja'far + Nuri have also thought
of him, we know privately from Ahmad Pasha. So I said
I had heard that they had discussed the possibility of
appointing him. Ja'far said yes, but he feared there
would be an outcry by the extremists. I pointed out that all the influential
people would look on him as a guarantee of stability
+ moreover that if you put a Basrah man into the
most important ministry, it would be very difficult for
Basrah to insist on administrative separation from
'Iraq . By this time Faisal , who had finished his
prayers, came back + Mr Cornwallis arrived to
talk business with him, so I took my leave a
second time + as I went down the steps with
Ja'far I rubbed the last argument well into
him. He was taken by it - I hope I'm right
about it, but it's Sir Percy's wish + he is not
often wrong. I told him the whole conversation
next day + he approved.
There's no doubt that this is the most absorbing job
that I've ever taken a hand in
The weather is a little cooler. One day last week
the
